As you might have noticed float division is not precise.
Small errors in the last digit can happen haphazardly.
This is caused the way how float numbers are represents on the hardware level.
You can read more about it on wikipedia.
If you want to have precise arithmetic in python it can be done with built-in module decimal:

code:
>>> from decimal import Decimal
>>> Decimal('1') / 3
Decimal('0.3333333333333333333333333333')

text: It's also possible to change precision:

code:
>>> from decimal import Decimal, getcontext
>>> getcontext().prec = 50
>>> Decimal('1') / 3
Decimal('0.33333333333333333333333333333333333333333333333333')

text: The rules are that if both input numbers are integers (no decimal point), the output will be an integer, otherwise it will be a float.
The float precision is defined by your system and if you want more precision than that, you need to use a library.
Google arbitrary precision math python.
If you want to divide two literal whole numbers and get a float, then it doesn't matter which one you give the decimal point to and there's no convention.
That's rare enough that it isn't something that too many people make rules about.
In Python 2, dividing an int by an int always truncates the result to an int.
However, if one or both operands are floats, then your answer is a float.

Division is a bit confusion topic in python.
The behavior of / depends on command line options:
In the new semantics / always produces a float.
In the old it produces an int if both operands are ints and a float if at least one of them is a float.
Check with your python version to determine which one is the default for you.

text: Note that there is also the truncating division operator: // which divides two numbers and truncates the result irrespective of their types.
It returns an int if arguments are both ints and float if at least one of them is a float.
The behavior of this operator doesn't depend on command line options.
